titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of the collection at Syracuse University
titlestmt.author: JA

list.item: 14 Sep 2020 - stage manager's script added; some items shifted from Box 2 to Box 3 (MRC)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Papers of the American poet, critic, dramatist, and editor. A single item of correspondence, and writings.
did.langmaterial: Majority in English, some in French

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Howard Moss (1922-1987) was an American poet, dramatist, children's author, editor, and critic. Born in New York City, he attended the University of Michigan 1939-1940 where he won a Hopwood Award; Harvard University during the summer of 1942; and received his BA from the University of Wisconsin in 1943. He later did graduate work at Columbia University.
Moss was an instructor at Vassar College in 1945-1946, and in 1948 became the Poetry Editor of The New Yorker magazine, a post he held for more than thirty-five years until his death in 1987.
Some of Moss' works include the following:

list.item: The Wound and the Weather, Reynal, 1943.
A Swimmer in the Air, Scribner, 1957.
A Winter Come, A Summer Gone, Poems 1946-1960, Scribner, 1960.
The Magic Lantern of Marcel Proust, Macmillan, 1962.

bioghist.p: Moss was awarded the 1972 National Book Award for his Selected Poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Howard Moss Collection consists of correspondence, criticism, drama, and poetry.
Correspondence contains one letter, written by Sinclair Lewis.
Criticism contains three book reviews and the manuscript for The Magic Lantern of Marcel Proust.
Drama contains successive drafts of two plays, The Folding Green and the Oedipus-Mah-Jongg Scandal.

Poetry includes material from three books of poetry (Finding Them Lost and Other Poems, Second Nature, and a children's collection, Tigers and Other Lilies) as well as individual poems. Types of material include holograph, typescripts, galley proofs, and a few printed copies of poems.

note.p: During processing, drafts were labelled e.g. A, B, C, etc. This was done with careful attention to paper characteristics, completeness of the manuscript, revisions and their subsequent incorporations, but these labels were designated solely at the processor's discretion, and should not be taken as either author's notation or as scholarly direction. In the seven versions of "The Folding Green", Moss does inscribe one as "Second version" and one as "Fourth version"; the researcher must choose his own path.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: Material is arranged alphabetically by type and, within each series, alphabetically by title.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Bulk of collection purchased in several lots, 1970. The Folding Green stage manager's script, gift of Kate Spector, 2019.

unittitle.emph: Finding Them Lost and Other Poems

did.abstract: holograph notes

scopecontent.p:
Contains the following:
"Another Life" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed (6 pp.)
"Arsenic" - galley proof for The New Yorker 10/5/66 (2pp.); typescript, holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (10 pp.)
"The Bay Stone" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed (10 pp.)
"Beach Glass" (also titled "Sea Glass") - galley proof for The New Yorker 11/ 2/66 (1 p.); See also "The Dune Wig"; typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (18pp.)
"Drinks with X, or The Woman in Black" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed (23 pp.)
"The Dune Wig" undated undated - typescript, holograph notes, signed (1 p.); See also "Beach Glass"
"Front Street" - galley proof for The New Yorker 3/14/66 (2pp.); typescript, holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (13 pp.)
"Going Dutch" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed (3 pp.)
"Great Spaces" undated - typescript, holograph notes, signed (1 p.)
"The Maid's Story" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, signed (4 pp.)
"The Meeting" - galley proof for The New Yorker 9/20/65 (1 p.); typescript, holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (2 pp.)
"Particular Beauties" - galley proof for The New Yorker 10/25/66 (1 p.) ; typescript, holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (4 pp.)
"Piano Practice" undated - typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, signed (13 pp.)
"Still Pond, No More Moving", galley proofs for The New Yorker - galley A 6/24/66 (3 pp.); galley B 9/21/65 - typescript notes (3 pp.); galley C 9/21/65 - holograph notes (3 pp.); typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, successive revisions, signed undated (35 pp.)
"The Vase" - galley proof for The New Yorker 11/17/66 (1 p.); typescript, typescript (carbon copy), holograph notes, signed undated (12 pp.)

did.abstract: typescript, holograph notes, successive revisions

arrangement.p: The persons in the poem "Lifelines" underwent a metamorphosis of names while the poem was evolving. Thus, fifteen names are titling five basic poems. No attempt was made to arrange these beyond the five divisions. All of the revisions and poems were kept together and not sorted individually into the larger alphabetic list.
